VOL. XXI, NO. 5.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 6, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

THE ELEVEN IS IMPROVING FAST

MEDS TO COME OUT FOR TEAM

SENIORS HONOR PROF. THOMAS

HOPKINS MAKES GREAT FIGHT

Men Put Up Splendid Fight on Saturday.
Showed That They Are Shaping
Into a Smooth-Running
Machine

Ten Men, Including.Leadbetter and Tillet, Give Their Names to Coach
Brennick—Appeal Made by
Hopkins Doctors.

Chosen Honorary President of 1917 Class.
Henry Baker Elected to Student
Council—Straus Tells of
Hullabaloo.

Black and Blue Eleven Holds the Swarthmore Team to Score of 14 to 6.
Outplays Opponents in
Second Half.

As a consequence of a meeting
of the Hopkins Medical School
students, held last Saturday
morning, ten men have reported
to Coach Brennick as candidates
for the team.
The following list is the only
official one, coming direct from
Mr. Brennick. Other men may report during the course of the
week, but those who have definitely decided to come out for the
team are as follows: Leadbetter,
Micklethwait, Martindale, Tillet,
Ormond, Finney, Jackson, Hartman, Stackford and Callender.
Jackson, Hartman, Martindale
and Finney have all been members of other Hopkins teams. Callender was a sub-quarter at Harvard. Tillet was on a University of Georgia team, and was
chosen all-Southern quarterback.
Not a man on the list is not an
experienced player or one whose
presence will not make a decided
addition to the Hopkins squad.
In addition, the majority of these
men are linesmen, who,at present,
are regarded as constituting the
Black and Blue's greatest need.
Throughout the season, efforts
have been constantly made to induce some or all of these men to
report for practice, but until last
Saturday these efforts were unavailing. At the meeting Saturday morning, however, Drs. Bridgman, Stone and Bernheim made
personal appeals to the men to
lend their efforts to the development of another championship
eleven—with the above list of recruits as a result.
The reluctance of the men to
practice with the team heretofore
has been due entirely to the
amount of work which study at the
Hopkins Medical School entails.
The hours run practically from
nine to five every day, and, in the
later years, often longer.
The Athletic Association is endeavoring to procure enough autos
to call for the men every day, so
as to bring them to Homewood
Field in the quickest possible
time after they are released from
the laboratory. It is extremely
improbable, however, that, even
with this convenience, the whole
squad can go into action soon
enough to obtain much daylight
scrimmage.

At a meeting of the Senior
Class, held last Friday, Prof. Carl
C. Thomas, professor of mechanical engineering and head of the
Hopkins Mechanical Engineering
School, was elected honorary class
president.
Professor Thomas, who has the
honor -of being the first man from
the Engineering School to be
chosen honorary president of a
graduating class, has won a nation-wide reputation by his work.
He has been connected with three
other universities besides Hopkins—Cornell, New York and
Wisconsin. At the first of these
he was professor of marine engineering and naval architecture;
at the second, professor of marine
engineering; and at the third, professor of steam and gas engineering.
The election of the honorary
president was the first business
of the day. .After it was concluded, President Sutton announced that another member was
to be elected to the Student Council. Henry Baker, of the Engineering School, was chosen to.this
position.
Sutton next announced that, to
follow up the way blazed by the
Junior Class, a committee of ten
had been appointed to arouse the
class' spirit in support of the
football team. The committee
consisted of Howard Wilson,
chairman; Firor, Hobleman,
Skinner Steinbach, Twigg, Cecil,
E. G. Hall, E. L. Smith and
Watson.
Henry Straus, editor-in-chief
of the 1917 Hullabaloo, then addressed the meeting, explaining
the change of purpose which the
editors had determined upon for
the book, and asking the support
of all for the benefit to be given
on November 24. He was followed by W. B. Baxley, who exhorted the class to support the
military training movement, not
only in principle, but in actual
report at the drills. •

In a game that will go down
in the annals of history as being
one of the most spirited contests
ever witnessed on Homewood
field, Hopkins 'vasity eleven was
defeated by Swarthmore on Saturday, 14 to 6.
Seldom has a Black and Blue
eleven played with more fight and
determination. Outweighed and
playing against a more experienced team, Hopkins held the visitors to two touchdowns, which
were scored by Swarthmore during the first 10 minutes of play.
Thereafter, especially during the
second half, Hopkins kept the ball
in the visitors' territory and prevented further scoring by the
Quakers by fighting against a superior team with apparently exhaustless spirit and energy. Their
reward, and what might be termed
the climax of their endeavors,
canVe during the last three minutes of play, when Hopkins, after
recovering the ball on a fumble
made by Swarthmore, scored a
touchdown.
The day was by no means ideal
for a football contest. On the
other hand, a drizzling rain kept
the field and ball very slippery,
and frequent fumbles by both
teams was the result. The bad
weather conditions kept most of
the indifferent class of spectators
indoors, but Hopkins' rooters
turned out in force and added to
the enthusiasm and spirit of the
affair.
The cheering and singing by the
rooting section was carried on in
a highly commendable manner.
It was clearly evident that the
yell practices of the past week
had done a world of good. The
cheering heretofore has been of a
very mediocre character, but last
Saturday the Black and Blue
rooting section really got behind
the team, and 'despite the weather
conditions, the cheers did not lag
as formerly.
However, the stands had good
cause to show their confidence in
the Black and Blue eleven. The
latter part of the second half was
about as thrilling as any ever
staged
on
Homewood
field.
Swarthmore had two touchdowns
to her credit, but try as they
might every time they started a
rally a fumble would intervene
and a Hopkins man would snatch
the ball. Hopkins thus had
several chances to score, but
missed by inches completing one

By COACH BRENNICK

On Saturday the team won the
praise of the student body, the
alumni, friends, and of the
coaches—and this notwithstanding the fact that they lost—because they played a fighting, spirited and intelligent game, such as
befitted a Hopkins team. In
Swarthmore they met one of the
best teams in the East, fresh from
its victory over Pennsylvania, so
that, playing as our team did, the
contest was a splendid one from
beginning to end. Our line again
distinguished itself, but the backfield came into its own also on
Saturday, and gives promise of
much greater development. Branham and Hopkins played great
football, both on offense and defense, and showed they were able
to stand up under heavy strain.
Calkins, a freshman, showed the
coaches that he has the makings
of a fine player, if the improvement he exhibited on Saturday is
continued. Every man that entered the contest showed that he
had fight and spirit, and even if
nothing else but these features
were shown, the team deserved the
congratulations given • them by
their fellow-students after the
game.
But fight and spirit alone do
not win football games. Indeed,
is it not the fact that the defeated
team often shows more spirit and
fight than the winner? What we
must have is an efficient team, a
team that can do the purely physical work in a more or less subconscious way while using their
brains to adjust themselves to the
various conditions which may confront them during a contest. The
first signs of this kind of a team
presented themselves Saturday,
and it was this aspect of the case
which was most pleasing to the
coaches and those who are closely
watching the team's development.
The past three games have
plainly indicated that, game and
spirited as our line is, it must be
strengthened if we are to successfully cope with future opponents.
The present line plays a splendid
defensive game, but when it comes
to lifting, on the offense, the
strength is wanting. This does
not mean that the present line is
to be discarded; far from it. It
contains too many splendid players; men who would be an addition to any team. They are fine
men for part of a game, but not

which will reach $150,000 or $200,000, have been under way since
early last summer at Delaware
College. They include a new agricultural building, two new dormitories, a renewed campus and numerous renovations of old buildings. The incentive which has induced this activity was a donation to the college of $100,000,
soon after school closed last
spring.

CLASS USED FOR EXPERIMENT
Professor Watson Takes Students of
Political Economy as Subjects for
Study of Effects of Advertising Physcology.

Whether the fact that their
deaths might leave their putative
wives and children destitute, or
the fact that, at sixty-five, they
might very easily develop into
burdens upon the community,
would be more likely to direct
their footsteps in the direction of
the nearest life insurance office,
was one of the questions which
last Tuesday the students in -political economy II suddenly found
themselves called upon to answer.
The occasion was an experiment arranged by Dr. John B.
Watson, professor of experimental and comparative psychology,
which had for its purpose the determination of the "pulling power" of various kinds of advertisements. An envelope containing
twelve slips, each slip having
upon it some argument in favor
of life insurance, was given to
every member of the class, and
the men were instructed to arrange and number the slips in accordance with the relative appeal
which they presented.
The twelve arguments submitted covered a wide field, ranging
from general statistical facts to
invocations of sentiments entirely
personal. There were cold, hard
references to the irrefutable proposition that all men are human,
tempting statements of the especial advantages which a life insurance policy offered as a form
of investment, touching pictures
of the pride and joy with which
an employer would call to his
arms the far-seeing employee who
would flaunt before his eyes the
receipt for his first premium. Incidentally, Professor Watson's array'of advertisements would have
proved excellent material for the
campaign of any life insurance
company.
Just why the thirty men studying public finance under Professor
Hollander should be chosen as the
subjects for the experiment is not
known. It has been casually mentioned by members of the class,
however, that the arguments all
seemed to be addressed to minds
of a high order of intelligence.
The results of the experiment
have not as yet been announced.
When procured, Professor Watson will use them as material for
the lectures on "Business Psychology" which he is delivering
every Thursday night.

1918 HAS A "PEP" COMMITTEE

Y. M. C. A. WANTS NEW MEMBERS APPOINTMENTS IN ENGINEERING

Junior Class Sets Rest of the University an Example—Yell Practices
Showing Good Effects of
the Movement.

Plans the Launching of Big Campaign.
Swartz Elected Vice-President of
Cabinet—Chen Heads Foreign
Student Committee.

Dr. Smallwood Made Teaching Fellow,
Mr. Dana Appointed Instructor,
and Miss Talbot Research Assistant.

Just how much spirit one class,
acting as a unit, can inject into
a university in which,for the past
month, spirit has been a somewhat negligible quantity, is now
being demonstrated to Johns Hopkins by the Class of 1918.
The first evidence of the new
element which has entered into
the football situation was given
last Wednesday. Many seniors,
sophomores and freshmen, as they
came into the door of the lectureroom of the Civil Engineering
Building, casually wondered what
had caused the enormous increase
in attendance which met their
eyes. As the crowd swelled larger
and larger, that wonder grew with
it—among all, except the juniors.
Two or three yells were given, and
then there arose a shout of "18
this way," and there was what
seemed to be a general migration
to the corner of the room where
Bob Duncan was perched on a
convenient window sill.
The rest of the men were impatiently awaiting an explanation
of these unexpected proceedings
—and Duncan gave it, in a short
speech entirely devoid of any attempt at inspiring rhetoric, but
which simply stated a fact. The
cheering and the support of the
football team in general had been
unmitigatedly rotten, he said;
something had to be done—and
the, juniors proposed doing it.
They were going to form a separate organization, stick together
at yell practices, and come out in
a body to watch the team scrimmage. Above everything, every
man in the class was to be part
of the unit. That was all.
Of course, that was not all. It
was not all at that cheering practice itself, the enthusiasm of
which showed to the Hopkins
freshmen a side of their University as yet unknown; nor was it
all when the football team last
Friday afternoon went through
their final evolutions before a
grandstand which had as many
wildly rooting men in it as had
the entire cheering section at any
of the preceding games. All the
freshmen were there that day,
marched up to Homewood Field
in military formation by Lieutenant Elliott, but even their superior, numbers could not make their
efforts surpass the concentrated
efforts of the proudly assembled
juniors.
The organization of the movement was very simple. There was
a class meeting last Tuesday, at
which some exceedingly earnest
speeches were made; a motion
was passed, and the "Pep" Committee, consisting of Sutton, chairman; Duncan, Wolfe, Chalmers
.and Woodward were appointed.
Then, on Wednesday, before Doc-

From Monday, November 13, to
Wednesday, November 15, the
Hopkins Y. M. C. A. will hold a
big membership campaign. Not
only will the Assciciation endeavor to have every student become a member of the Association
by paying the annual dues of one
dollar, but it will also try to get
as many men as possible interested in the active work of the
Association.
At a meeting of the Y. M. C. A.
cabinet last Monday, William H.
Swartz, '18, was elected vicepresident of the Association.
Swartz was a member of the cabinet last year and is active in
other fields of student activities.
H. C. Chen, '17, was appointed
chairmen of the Foreign Students'
Committee. Chen has long been
a leader of the foreign students
and has been chosen president of
the Chinese Club of this city.
With the selection of these two
men, the Y. M. C. A. Cabinet for
this year now stands complete.
Prof. C. J. Tilden led the chapel
services during the past week, taking up the story of Paul's missionary journeys, as told in the
Acts. Rev. Layfield will be leader
this week and a large crowd is
desired.
Mr. Joshua Levering entertained all the foreign students in
the city at his country home at
Buxton last Saturday afternoon
from 2 until 6 o'clock. Charles
D. Hurry, S. J. Chuan and Mr.
Purralta, all of the International
Committee for Work Among Foreign Students, were also present.

MISS GILMAN UNDERTAKES
FURNISHING OF RECEPTION HALL

MADISON AVENUE COR. FORTY-FOURTH STREET
NEW YORK

In honor of her father, the late
Daniel Coit Gilman, the first
president of the Johns Hopkins
University, Miss Elizabeth Gilman is having four chandeliers,
masterpieces of one of the best
glass factories in New York, installed in the reception hall of the
Academic Building.
Miss Gilman is also having
four busts, including one of her
father, prepared, which are to be
placed in the corners of the hall.
Besides this, she intends to present the University with an elaborate set of furniture to adorn this
same room.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 6, 1916.

TECH SCHOLARSHIPS AWARDED

TOTAL ENROLLMENT NEAR 2500

Number of Applicants this Year Sets
Record—Only Few Appointments
Competitive —List of Men
Seeking Scholarships.

Far Exceeds Record of Any Previous
Year—Registrar Gives Approximate Number in Each
Department.

At a recent meeting of the
Hopkins Scholarship Board, appointees for the senatorial and
ordinary scholarships in Baltimore, as well as throughout the
State, were named. Applicants
for the scholarships this year
were more numerous than ever
before, and in several cases competitors for the appointment were
quite close.
Comparatively few of the scholarships this year were competitive,
outside of those awarded to residents in the city. In the counties, where application for the
coveted opportunity is not great,

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 6, 1916.
A Defeat That Is a Victory.

back.
come
has
Hopkins
Whether we win the State championship or lose it, that much is
known to every man who, in that
drizzling rain, saw the eleven
which had been ridiculed by all
the papers in the city hold down
one of the strongest elevens of the
East to a score of 14 to 6.
Before that game the only discrepancy in the forecasts was
whether the final score would be
40, or 60, to 0. And yet Hopkins
held Swarthmore to two touchdowns, both made in the first half.
Outweighed, playing against a
frankly superior team, Hopkins
gritted its teeth and fought—and
fought so well that the struggle
became equal.
The team has found itself; the
University is lined up behind it;
all Hopkins is in fighting trim.
Whether we win the championship or lose it, there could have
been no better prelude to the first
real struggle for its possession
than last Saturday's defeat.
An Inadvisable Change.

Since its first publication, the
Hullabaloo has been the book of
one class. In it each successive
group of graduates has found its
expression; consciously or unconsciously, it has depicted the Hopkins senior. For that reason, the
book has meant something—has

been more than a mere publication. It has belonged to the
seniors; they have felt that it has
belonged to them, and they have
made it worthy.
Yet, although the Hullabaloos
of the past have been pre-eminently class books, every under-graduate institution and interest has
had representation in their pages,
every under-graduate class has
had its own separate section—
with the proportion always maintained. A change in Hullabaloo
policy can mean only one thing—
that proportion is to be destroyed; with the exception of the
photographs and write-ups of the
graduates, the Hullabaloo of the
future is not to be a senior book.
Hopkins does not need an under-graduate annal. As a matter
of fact, it does not want an under-graduate annal. The Hullabaloo should be supported by
every under-classman, but it
should be supported because it is
a Hopkins institution, not because
that under-classman happens to
have a photograph displayed on
one of its pages.
In the Hullabaloos of the past,
the seniors have been given that
peculiar sense of individual possession that comes to men when
they feel that a thing has grown
up in their own image. The Hullabaloo, as a class book, has been
a personal bond between those,
who, for four years, have worked
and lived together, a bond that an
under-graduate annal could never
be. The Hullabaloo has belonged
to the seniors—and it has belonged to them of right.
This is not the narrower policy;
it is the broader one. Breadth of
vision does not necessarily go
with mere expanse of canvas.
And, because it has been the book
of one class and one class alone,
the Hullabaloo of the past has reflected its University in the only
way that a University can be reflected in printed pages—in the
tone in which those pages are conceived.
TIIE NEWS-LETTER has the greatest respect for the opinions of the
members of the 1917 Hullabaloo
Board, but if feels constrained to
state that it believes the change
which that board has announced
in the nature of the Hullabaloo
to be an inadvisable one.

into the limbo of the departed, it
was last Wednesday. That sign
was given, given at what we devoutly hope was the end of the
most dreary, listless, and enervating series of yell practices
(Heaven save the mark!) which
has ever disgraced our University.
Just what the juniors did, and
how they did it, is known to every
Hopkins man. Just what results
their action will have, or rather,
how long the results will last, is
known to no one. But the great
merit of the "Pep" Committee
which they appointed consists in
the very fact of its appointment;
it shows that one class, at least,
has still enough fire, enough backbone, enough vision, to start something—and, in its history, Hopkins was never in more patent
need for something to be started.
The action which created the
committee has been followed up
by the men responsible for it, and
followed up with an enthusiasm
to which the last two yell practices bear ample witness. The
movement to which it has given
rise may eliminate a few rather
tough problems, or it may only
precipitate them, but on one point
the University is united-1918 is
distinctly a class.
The Battalion.

That the inauguration of military training has met with the approval of the Hopkins student
body, and that the battalion itself is in a highly satisfactory
state of development, the drills on
the campus are evidencing without a shadow of doubt. Lieutenant Elliott has shown himself to
be an organizer who knows how to
combine the necessary amount of
disciplinary strictness with the
rare capacity of arousing and sustaining undergraduate enthusiasm, and the heartiness of the response with which he has met has
been unmistakable.
There is a peculiarly exhilarating sensation in being in the forerank of a movement, especially
when that movement has already
met with nation-wide approval.
Military training at colleges, it
must be remembered, save in cadet
institutions of long standing, is
scarcely a year old — and last
spring men were drilling in front
of Gilman Hall. We have not, of
course, made as rapid strides in
the movement as have such univerThe "Pep" Committee.
sities as Harvard, where there is

Hopkins needed an overt sign to two or three thousand; as yet,
show that, so far as the spirit of we have no fully equipped regiits undergraduates was concerned, ment, ready to take the field at a

moment's notice, but, in proportion to our size, we have done as
much as any college in the
country, and, irrespective of our
size, the marchers on the campus
are already an entirely presentable aggregation.
Yet the appeal has gone out for
enough upper-classmen to bring
the battalion up to full strength
—and that appeal should be answered. The number of sophomores, juniors and seniors now
drilling with the corps has shown
that the movement has a firmer
basis than mere compulsion; every
additional recruit indicates still
more clearly that military training has come to Hopkins to stay.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 6, 1916.

Herbert Baxter Adams Leader ofAmerican Historical Study
WAS EDITOR OF COLLEGE PAPER

WORK AT HOPKINS POINTED WAY
Organized First Historical Seminary in
America--President Wilson Calls
Him "Captain of Systematic Scholarship."
By PROF. JOHN H. LATANE'

is hard for those of us who
were here in the nineties to realize that to the students now in
residence, and even to some members of the faculty, Herbert B.
Adams is merely a name. To us
he is still a very real personality.
We remember him as the embodiment of energy and initiative, influential in all University affairs
and actively interested in those
matters which touched the life of
the community, for he believed
with Jules Siegfried that the
"education of the people is the
first duty of democracy."
Adams was a native of Massachusetts, and came of old New
England stock. After graduating
from Amherst College and teaching Latin, Greek, mathematics
and classical history at Williston
Seminary for a year, he went to
Germany, and in 1870 received
the degree of doctor of philosophy
at Heidelberg. That very year
the - Johns Hopkins University
opened its doors to students, offering opportunities for investigation and research which had
never before been available in
America. Adams at once applied
for and was awarded a fellowship
and was thus the first appointee
to that honor in'the department
of history. He held in succession
the positions of lecturer, associate, associate professor and professor, and his connection with
the University continued until
shortly before his death in 1901.
Adams' activities at the Johns
Hopkins University were so
varied that it is impossible to
speak of them all in this brief
sketch. He organized the first historical seminary in America, and,
in order to provide for the publication of his own monographs and
those of his students, he started
the studies in historical and political science. During his lifetime
he edited about forty volumes,
and since his death one or more
volumes have been issued each
year. This series revolutionized
the study of history in America.
His students were set to work on
special topics in limited fields of
investigation. His first students
were drawn mainly from New England, and they were put to work
on the local history of the New
England States. Soon, however,
graduate students came to Baltimore from Virginia and the other
Southern States, and they were
set to work on the local and institutional history of the South.
Adams realized that the history
of the United States could not be
It

With this issue, THE NEWS-LETTER begins a series of
articles upon the lives and works of some of the men whose
efforts, more than any other factor, have given the Johns
Hopkins University the reputation which it enjoys today.
Herbert Baxter Adams may truly be called the father of
modern historical study in America. Through the ideals which
he shaped at this University, a new conception of historical research was spread among the intellectual centers of the country. In him was personified the breadth of thought, the
passion for truth, the vision, which have come down to us as
the most cherished traditions of the Hopkins scholar.
Yet, absorbed in his work as he was, Adams always took
a keen interest in undergraduate affairs. The memory of that
interest is perpetuated by the Adams medal, given every year,
through his generosity,to the best public speaker in the second
year, by the Adams prize of books, awarded at the annual
Senior-Junior debate, and by the Adams Literary Society,
named in his honor.
written on a large scale until
local and obscure sources were
made available through monographs in the field of biography
and local history. The monographic method which he employed was soon adopted in other
American universities, and the
Studies in Historical and Political
Science have been widely imitated
until now almost every university
in the land has a series of its own.
Adams was not a profound
scholar, for his interests took too
wide a range. Neither did he
leave behind him any great piece
of historical work, for, with the

exception of his "Life of Jared
Sparks," an excellent biography
in two volumes, his own contributions were chiefly monographic.
But it is as an organizer of historical studies and a promoter of
new methods of historical research that he will be remembered. His enthusiasm was contagious, and this was the secret..
of his great success. He had the
rare faculty of making his students
think that the subject which
claimed his attention for the time
being in his lecture courses was
the most important subject in the

HERBERT BAXTER ADAMS

Historian Ascribed Much of His Later
Interest in Editing to Early Journalistic Training—Sketch
of His Career.

Herbert Baxter Adams was
born at Shutesbury (near Amherst), Mass., on April 16, 1850.
Doctor Adams' early life was
spent amidst the pleasant surroundings of Hampshire County.
His mother and father were both
of hearty New England stock,
• their Puritan ancestors first settling in Massachusetts in 1634.
Adams' education and training
was in large part due to the kindly help and advice of his eldest brother, Charles Dickinson
Adams.
Adams' mother had moved with
her sons, after their father's
death, to Amherst. It was in the
classical environment of this town
that Adams had his first schooling. Later, his eldest brother was
instrumental in having him enter
Phillips Exeter Academy. Here
he graduated at the head of his
class in 1868. The next fall he
entered Amherst College, winning
the Porter prize for the best entrance examinations.
It was while at Amherst that the
first real influences were present
that developed in Doctor Adams
his remarkable abilities as a
teacher and an editor. He did
not decide to make history his
life work until his last year at
college; in fact, he did not specialize in history until he took up
graduate work after leaving Amherst. President Seelye, of Amherst, was the man who decided
Adams on his career. In one of
his philosophy lectures President
Seelye, who had long known and
helped Adams, discussed the philosophy of history. It was this
lecture that turned Adams toward
the study which he made his life
work.
Before that time, Herbert
Adams had looked forward to
journalism as a profession. He
had reported at odd times for
Amherst, New York and Boston
papers, and had spent many hours
of his time in college in writing
for his college paper.
Adams once said of this: "My
editorial connection with The
Amherst Student really gave a
permanent bent- to my life. I
learned more real useful knowledge in that voluntary connection
than in all other college means
of training; in punctuation, composition, and rhetoric. To this
day I can discern more lasting
influences proceeding from that
editorial den of mine at Amherst
than from any other one college
source. I have forgotten my
mathematics, which I always

In 1872 Doctor Adams graduated from Amherst at the head of
his class. He then taught for a
year at Williston Seminary, where
he instructed in Latin, Greek, mathematics and classical history.
After teaching for a year at Williston, his elder brother persuaded him to go to Germany and
take up the graduate work in history.
He first went to Lausanne,
Switzerland, where he studied
French. This was followed by a
few months' study in Italy, after
which he came to Paris. Here his
elder brother, on a trip abroad,
met him and persuaded him to go
to Heidelberg immediately. He
studied at this institution for a
year, and the following winter
saw him at the University of Berlin. Becoming disheartened the
next season at the thought of the
elaborate course of study necessary for a doctor's degree.at Berlin, he decided to return to America, and was' only persuaded to
stay in Germany by his brother,
who influenced him through his
letters to return to Heidelberg.
Here, in 1876, he completed a
course in historical and political
science, under the guidance of
Prof. J. C. Bluntschli, who was
largely instrumental in having

Adams appointed the first Fellow
in history at the Johns Hopkins
University, when the University
was opened in 1876. Adams received his doctor's degree at Heidelberg with highest honors.

An Appreciation.

To the Editor of THE News-LEI-ma:
Sir—If Hopkins were the butt
of a few things as "rotten"—that
is what the powers-that-be called
it—as was "A Would-Be Rooter's"
letter, maybe we would find a
place on the sporting page of an
out-of-town daily. Perhaps the
vapors that hang over the stagnate managerial pool are not as
dense as "A Would-Be Rooter"
has pictured them, but at that
there's something rotten in Denmark, and it isn't last week's
bomb. All the folks agreed it
wasn't the letter that packed the
mass-meeting Wednesday! It was
the temperature or the canning
industry in Alaska, perhaps. And
maybe, the Aurora Borealis woke
the juniors up and made them
start something! It wasn't the
letter—oh, no!
The man who wrote that letter
slipped up once or twice — he
didn't quite get all of his arguments across—but he should be
congratulated upon raising a lone,
courageous voice in the hour of
Hopkins' dire need. Let the
various managers and their assistants stop telling us about the
letter and show us something—
something really constructive.
Let's have rallies before the
games, and give the teams sendoffs on the last practices—not a
half-hearted "hullabaloo," but a
parade and demonstration. Let's
have a truly Hopkins team, and
then we will develop a truly Hopkins spirit. Far better a 99-pound
freshman who is out every day for
practice on the line than an indifferent "Med" who has to be
begged to play.
Hats off to the lone voice from
the darkness!
ANOTHER WOULD-BE ROOTER.
November 1, 1916.
Another.

To the Editor of THE NEws-LETTEE:
Sir — Allow me to congratulate, through your columns, the
"Would-Be Rooter" who has so
aptly and fearlessly expressed the
sentiments of many others beside
himself, concerning the football
situation. He has, to my mind,
shown the conditions in their true
light. Our Athletic Association
must discard its antediluvian
ideas and principles, or else we
must discard our antediluvian
Athletic Association and form a
new and up-to-date one in its

place. Year after year, have our
athletics been allowed to drift—
we have not endeavored to keep
pace with the modernized systems
of other universities. Our Athletic Association is not asleep it
is dead. And unless it is resurrected quickly, the last rites must
be administered, and a new. Athletic Association must be formed,
with the energy and ability to
put through its plans.
Can you "resurrect," Athletic
Association?
Prove it!
What are you going to do about
daylight practice?
What are you going to do about
the persuasion of stubborn parents of good football material?
What are you going to do about
a real band?
What are you going to do about
the fellows who won't yell?
How are you going to solve the
X.
football situation?
November 1, 1916.

To the Editor of THE NEws-LtrrEE:
Sir — I wish to express my
hearty approval of the "Would-Be
Rooter's" article which appeared
in last week's issue of THE NEWSLETTER. I Wish to express my approval and to add more concerning things that have come to light
since that article appeared.
First and foremost is the comeback in spirit that Hopkins had
last week and which was manifest
in the splendid fight which the
football team put up against
Swarthmore. If anyone who saw
Hopkins play on Saturday for the
first time had been told that Hopkins' spirit had been admitted by
almost everyone a week before to
be nil, he would have laughed at
the very idea. Whether it was
the 1918 "Pep" Committee or the
"Would-Be Rooter's" letter that
started the awakening, we do not
know. At any rate, the old-time
spirit has returned.
Next comes the proposed Medical School team. Every Hopkins
student appreciates the feeling
that has urged the medical men
to action. But is it fair to the
undergraduates who have played
on the team so far, to the few
medical students who have conscientiously worked for the team
all season and to the other Maryland State teams to put a team
of stars from other colleges on
the field and call them Hopkins'
team? If we are to have a team
of Penfields and Leadbetters, why
does not the Athletic Association
arrange a schedule that includes
teams of the class these men are
accustomed to oppose? In my
opinion, and in the opinion of
many other Hopkins students, it
is far better to have a team on the
field that will fight like our team
did against Swarthmore and lose,
than to accept the charity of
the medical students and win.

November 4, 1916.
Down With College Spirit!

the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Sir—Your columns this year
have been filled with appeals for
"college spirit." May I venture
a lone voice against "college
spirit" and all that comes with it.
The undergraduate department is
at present in a state of transition.
It has two possibilities:
1. To lose its individuality
and become an average, small college, examples of which are dotted
all over the country. Sad to say,
the removal to Homewood, from
which so much was expected, is
facilitating that. •
2. The other possibility is to
return to the place we occupied
ten years ago. To have the undergraduate department be a vital
part of that institution of learning we so proudly call "The Johns
Hopkins University." I therefor
wish to sound a call for "university spirit," a spirit which should
strive for things higher than a
State football championship.
JUNIOR.
October 31, 1916.
To

Re-enter the "Would-Be Rooter."
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LEVER:

Sir—Have we no pride? Have
we no self-respect? Are we totally
void of any self-esteem? Reports
are being circulated that the
Medical School is organizing a
football team of "old-timers," and
lacks but three backfield men.
We are to supply them. Then,
these veterans are to proceed to
win the Maryland (minus Annapolis) State championship. Is
there no one else in this whole
University who will stand up with
me and say: "We don't want
them !" We don't want the State
championship if we must take
second-hand players, who have left
their college spirit with their respective colleges, and are at Hopkins to study medicine! We don't
want the State championship
anyway, because it has no meaning!
Wake up Does no one realize
that this is no way to carry on
our athletics? I reiterate that
we must stop the Athletic Association from pursuing its
policy: "Give us enough ready developed men and we will turn out
a successful team." Examine the
list of men on this Medical School
team, as given by The Sun. Few
are Hopkins men who have spent
their under-graduate days playing for us. Two are Princeton

men, one having been a varsity
player in 1912. Three have already been captains at their respective colleges. Do you get my
point? Why should we be thrilled
by the performance of such men?
We should be ashamed to appear
at all within Homewood field, to
acknowledge that such is the
team we adnlit to be our representative.
Suppose these old-timers, in
spite of their radiantly glorious
reputation, proceed to lose the
Western Maryland game. What
then? Will an all-providing Athletic Association proceed to call
a special session and agree to
spend a few extra dollars and
have the "band" on the field Monday afternoon at the beginning of
practice? Will the four undergraduate classes appear in a mass
and march around the field and
cheer themselves hoarse to show
the team (the old-timers) that in
spite of the fact that they have
lost the State championship
there is still the St. John's game?
That is virtually what occurred at
the University of Pennsylvania
after they lost their first game.
But, will we do it? Why should
we do it? It certainly won't make
the old-timers play better!
But, suppose they win—what a
glorious victory it will be! How
proud we shall be of our University! The first real game for the
State championship will have been
won—through charity. Or, do
you frankly believe that these oldtimers are to play spontaneously,
because of their love for Johns
Hopkins University?
The prime object of a team is
not merely to win games (for if it
were we could hire professionals) ;
its object is to represent its college
upon the athletic field. To accept
such a team as we are about to
place in the field is to admit that
the undergraduate department is
a nonentity. Why should we
come week after week to see a
team consisting of men whom we
hardly know to speak to, except
perhaps through our fraternal
affiliation? If, however, we are to
accept this Medical School team,
I respectfully suggest to the Athletic Association that it organize
four class teams and conduct a
series of interclass games. Personally, I would rather root for
my class team than for a team of
men whom I don't know to speak
to, even though the latter be playing for the "State" championship.

forward pass after another, any

line.
The stands fairly went wild
with excitement, for at last it
looked like a sure touchdown for
Hopkins. Captain Brooks was
sent in to supply the necessary
punch. On the first two plays he

in the same position as before.
With but one down left in which
to carry the ball over, Gatchell
was sent in with instructions
which resulted in an off-tackle
play for a touchdown. Martin,
quarterback, faked a pass to
Brooks, who paved the way for
Byrd Hopkins to take the ball
across. Branham failed at goal.
The resulting touchdown was a
virtual victory for the Black and
Blue. When the half ended a
few minutes later 'the Hopkins
student body rushed out on the
field to congratulate the members
of its team. An impromptu snake
dance was given, and after a
large "H" had been formed in the
center of the field, the students
retired to outside the locker
room, where Coach Brennick, Assistant Coach Wilkinson and
every member of the Black and
Blue team was given a hearty and
well-rounded cheer. The scene in
many ways resembled the winning
of an important State game and
emphasized the added interest
taken in the team during the past
week.
Swarthmore scored her two
touchdowns during the first part
of the first quarter. When the Quakers got the ball in the opening period they were unable to
advance the pigskin by straight
line plays and so were compelled
to rely on the aerial route. The
ball was gradually worked up
through Hopkins' territory on a
series of beautiful forward passes.
Finally, the visitors were within
striking distance of goal and
again failing to gain through the
line, attempted a pass, which this
time failed of completion. The ball
went over the goal line and was
given to Hopkins. Gorman punted and the Quakers, having the
ball once more, settled down for
a touchdown. Additional forward
passes by Swarthmore, and the
ball was on Hopkins' 10-yard line.
Hopkins' line braced, but was unable to hold the Quakers, and the
pigskin was taken over for the

Cornog, fullback for Swarthmore.
Michael kicked goal.
Hopkins kept the ball in

few minutes of play.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 6, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

THE ELEVEN IS IMPROVING FAST

MEDS TO COME OUT FOR TEAM

SENIORS HONOR PROF. THOMAS

HOPKINS MAKES GREAT FIGHT

Men Put Up Splendid Fight on Saturday.
Showed That They Are Shaping
Into a Smooth-Running
Machine

Ten Men, Including.Leadbetter and Tillet, Give Their Names to Coach
Brennick—Appeal Made by
Hopkins Doctors.

Chosen Honorary President of 1917 Class.
Henry Baker Elected to Student
Council—Straus Tells of
Hullabaloo.

Black and Blue Eleven Holds the Swarthmore Team to Score of 14 to 6.
Outplays Opponents in
Second Half.

As a consequence of a meeting
of the Hopkins Medical School
students, held last Saturday
morning, ten men have reported
to Coach Brennick as candidates
for the team.
The following list is the only
official one, coming direct from
Mr. Brennick. Other men may report during the course of the
week, but those who have definitely decided to come out for the
team are as follows: Leadbetter,
Micklethwait, Martindale, Tillet,
Ormond, Finney, Jackson, Hartman, Stackford and Callender.
Jackson, Hartman, Martindale
and Finney have all been members of other Hopkins teams. Callender was a sub-quarter at Harvard. Tillet was on a University of Georgia team, and was
chosen all-Southern quarterback.
Not a man on the list is not an
experienced player or one whose
presence will not make a decided
addition to the Hopkins squad.
In addition, the majority of these
men are linesmen, who,at present,
are regarded as constituting the
Black and Blue's greatest need.
Throughout the season, efforts
have been constantly made to induce some or all of these men to
report for practice, but until last
Saturday these efforts were unavailing. At the meeting Saturday morning, however, Drs. Bridgman, Stone and Bernheim made
personal appeals to the men to
lend their efforts to the development of another championship
eleven—with the above list of recruits as a result.
The reluctance of the men to
practice with the team heretofore
has been due entirely to the
amount of work which study at the
Hopkins Medical School entails.
The hours run practically from
nine to five every day, and, in the
later years, often longer.
The Athletic Association is endeavoring to procure enough autos
to call for the men every day, so
as to bring them to Homewood
Field in the quickest possible
time after they are released from
the laboratory. It is extremely
improbable, however, that, even
with this convenience, the whole
squad can go into action soon
enough to obtain much daylight
scrimmage.

At a meeting of the Senior
Class, held last Friday, Prof. Carl
C. Thomas, professor of mechanical engineering and head of the
Hopkins Mechanical Engineering
School, was elected honorary class
president.
Professor Thomas, who has the
honor -of being the first man from
the Engineering School to be
chosen honorary president of a
graduating class, has won a nation-wide reputation by his work.
He has been connected with three
other universities besides Hopkins—Cornell, New York and
Wisconsin. At the first of these
he was professor of marine engineering and naval architecture;
at the second, professor of marine
engineering; and at the third, professor of steam and gas engineering.
The election of the honorary
president was the first business
of the day. .After it was concluded, President Sutton announced that another member was
to be elected to the Student Council. Henry Baker, of the Engineering School, was chosen to.this
position.
Sutton next announced that, to
follow up the way blazed by the
Junior Class, a committee of ten
had been appointed to arouse the
class' spirit in support of the
football team. The committee
consisted of Howard Wilson,
chairman; Firor, Hobleman,
Skinner Steinbach, Twigg, Cecil,
E. G. Hall, E. L. Smith and
Watson.
Henry Straus, editor-in-chief
of the 1917 Hullabaloo, then addressed the meeting, explaining
the change of purpose which the
editors had determined upon for
the book, and asking the support
of all for the benefit to be given
on November 24. He was followed by W. B. Baxley, who exhorted the class to support the
military training movement, not
only in principle, but in actual
report at the drills. •

In a game that will go down
in the annals of history as being
one of the most spirited contests
ever witnessed on Homewood
field, Hopkins 'vasity eleven was
defeated by Swarthmore on Saturday, 14 to 6.
Seldom has a Black and Blue
eleven played with more fight and
determination. Outweighed and
playing against a more experienced team, Hopkins held the visitors to two touchdowns, which
were scored by Swarthmore during the first 10 minutes of play.
Thereafter, especially during the
second half, Hopkins kept the ball
in the visitors' territory and prevented further scoring by the
Quakers by fighting against a superior team with apparently exhaustless spirit and energy. Their
reward, and what might be termed
the climax of their endeavors,
canVe during the last three minutes of play, when Hopkins, after
recovering the ball on a fumble
made by Swarthmore, scored a
touchdown.
The day was by no means ideal
for a football contest. On the
other hand, a drizzling rain kept
the field and ball very slippery,
and frequent fumbles by both
teams was the result. The bad
weather conditions kept most of
the indifferent class of spectators
indoors, but Hopkins' rooters
turned out in force and added to
the enthusiasm and spirit of the
affair.
The cheering and singing by the
rooting section was carried on in
a highly commendable manner.
It was clearly evident that the
yell practices of the past week
had done a world of good. The
cheering heretofore has been of a
very mediocre character, but last
Saturday the Black and Blue
rooting section really got behind
the team, and 'despite the weather
conditions, the cheers did not lag
as formerly.
However, the stands had good
cause to show their confidence in
the Black and Blue eleven. The
latter part of the second half was
about as thrilling as any ever
staged
on
Homewood
field.
Swarthmore had two touchdowns
to her credit, but try as they
might every time they started a
rally a fumble would intervene
and a Hopkins man would snatch
the ball. Hopkins thus had
several chances to score, but
missed by inches completing one

By COACH BRENNICK

On Saturday the team won the
praise of the student body, the
alumni, friends, and of the
coaches—and this notwithstanding the fact that they lost—because they played a fighting, spirited and intelligent game, such as
befitted a Hopkins team. In
Swarthmore they met one of the
best teams in the East, fresh from
its victory over Pennsylvania, so
that, playing as our team did, the
contest was a splendid one from
beginning to end. Our line again
distinguished itself, but the backfield came into its own also on
Saturday, and gives promise of
much greater development. Branham and Hopkins played great
football, both on offense and defense, and showed they were able
to stand up under heavy strain.
Calkins, a freshman, showed the
coaches that he has the makings
of a fine player, if the improvement he exhibited on Saturday is
continued. Every man that entered the contest showed that he
had fight and spirit, and even if
nothing else but these features
were shown, the team deserved the
congratulations given • them by
their fellow-students after the
game.
But fight and spirit alone do
not win football games. Indeed,
is it not the fact that the defeated
team often shows more spirit and
fight than the winner? What we
must have is an efficient team, a
team that can do the purely physical work in a more or less subconscious way while using their
brains to adjust themselves to the
various conditions which may confront them during a contest. The
first signs of this kind of a team
presented themselves Saturday,
and it was this aspect of the case
which was most pleasing to the
coaches and those who are closely
watching the team's development.
The past three games have
plainly indicated that, game and
spirited as our line is, it must be
strengthened if we are to successfully cope with future opponents.
The present line plays a splendid
defensive game, but when it comes
to lifting, on the offense, the
strength is wanting. This does
not mean that the present line is
to be discarded; far from it. It
contains too many splendid players; men who would be an addition to any team. They are fine
men for part of a game, but not

CLASS USED FOR EXPERIMENT
Professor Watson Takes Students of
Political Economy as Subjects for
Study of Effects of Advertising Physcology.

Whether the fact that their
deaths might leave their putative
wives and children destitute, or
the fact that, at sixty-five, they
might very easily develop into
burdens upon the community,
would be more likely to direct
their footsteps in the direction of
the nearest life insurance office,
was one of the questions which
last Tuesday the students in -political economy II suddenly found
themselves called upon to answer.
The occasion was an experiment arranged by Dr. John B.
Watson, professor of experimental and comparative psychology,
which had for its purpose the determination of the "pulling power" of various kinds of advertisements. An envelope containing
twelve slips, each slip having
upon it some argument in favor
of life insurance, was given to
every member of the class, and
the men were instructed to arrange and number the slips in accordance with the relative appeal
which they presented.
The twelve arguments submitted covered a wide field, ranging
from general statistical facts to
invocations of sentiments entirely
personal. There were cold, hard
references to the irrefutable proposition that all men are human,
tempting statements of the especial advantages which a life insurance policy offered as a form
of investment, touching pictures
of the pride and joy with which
an employer would call to his
arms the far-seeing employee who
would flaunt before his eyes the
receipt for his first premium. Incidentally, Professor Watson's array'of advertisements would have
proved excellent material for the
campaign of any life insurance
company.
Just why the thirty men studying public finance under Professor
Hollander should be chosen as the
subjects for the experiment is not
known. It has been casually mentioned by members of the class,
however, that the arguments all
seemed to be addressed to minds
of a high order of intelligence.
The results of the experiment
have not as yet been announced.
When procured, Professor Watson will use them as material for
the lectures on "Business Psychology" which he is delivering
every Thursday night.

1918 HAS A "PEP" COMMITTEE

Y. M. C. A. WANTS NEW MEMBERS APPOINTMENTS IN ENGINEERING

Junior Class Sets Rest of the University an Example—Yell Practices
Showing Good Effects of
the Movement.

Plans the Launching of Big Campaign.
Swartz Elected Vice-President of
Cabinet—Chen Heads Foreign
Student Committee.

Dr. Smallwood Made Teaching Fellow,
Mr. Dana Appointed Instructor,
and Miss Talbot Research Assistant.

Just how much spirit one class,
acting as a unit, can inject into
a university in which,for the past
month, spirit has been a somewhat negligible quantity, is now
being demonstrated to Johns Hopkins by the Class of 1918.
The first evidence of the new
element which has entered into
the football situation was given
last Wednesday. Many seniors,
sophomores and freshmen, as they
came into the door of the lectureroom of the Civil Engineering
Building, casually wondered what
had caused the enormous increase
in attendance which met their
eyes. As the crowd swelled larger
and larger, that wonder grew with
it—among all, except the juniors.
Two or three yells were given, and
then there arose a shout of "18
this way," and there was what
seemed to be a general migration
to the corner of the room where
Bob Duncan was perched on a
convenient window sill.
The rest of the men were impatiently awaiting an explanation
of these unexpected proceedings
—and Duncan gave it, in a short
speech entirely devoid of any attempt at inspiring rhetoric, but
which simply stated a fact. The
cheering and the support of the
football team in general had been
unmitigatedly rotten, he said;
something had to be done—and
the, juniors proposed doing it.
They were going to form a separate organization, stick together
at yell practices, and come out in
a body to watch the team scrimmage. Above everything, every
man in the class was to be part
of the unit. That was all.
Of course, that was not all. It
was not all at that cheering practice itself, the enthusiasm of
which showed to the Hopkins
freshmen a side of their University as yet unknown; nor was it
all when the football team last
Friday afternoon went through
their final evolutions before a
grandstand which had as many
wildly rooting men in it as had
the entire cheering section at any
of the preceding games. All the
freshmen were there that day,
marched up to Homewood Field
in military formation by Lieutenant Elliott, but even their superior, numbers could not make their
efforts surpass the concentrated
efforts of the proudly assembled
juniors.
The organization of the movement was very simple. There was
a class meeting last Tuesday, at
which some exceedingly earnest
speeches were made; a motion
was passed, and the "Pep" Committee, consisting of Sutton, chairman; Duncan, Wolfe, Chalmers
.and Woodward were appointed.
Then, on Wednesday, before Doc-

At a meeting of the Y. M. C. A.

Swartz, '18, was elected vicepresident of the Association.
Swartz was a member of the cabinet last year and is active in
other fields of student activities.
H. C. Chen, '17, was appointed
chairmen of the Foreign Students'

a leader of the foreign students
and has been chosen president of
the Chinese Club of this city.
With the selection of these two
men, the Y. M. C. A. Cabinet for
this year now stands complete.
Prof. C. J. Tilden led the chapel

desired.

D. Hurry, S. J. Chuan and Mr.
Purralta, all of the International
Committee for Work Among Foreign Students, were also present.

At a recent meeting of the
Hopkins Scholarship Board, appointees for the senatorial and
ordinary scholarships in Baltimore, as well as throughout the
State, were named. Applicants
for the scholarships this year
were more numerous than ever
before, and in several cases competitors for the appointment were

Comparatively few of the scholarships this year were competitive,

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 6, 1916.
A Defeat That Is a Victory.

back.
come
has
Hopkins
Whether we win the State championship or lose it, that much is
known to every man who, in that
drizzling rain, saw the eleven
which had been ridiculed by all
the papers in the city hold down
one of the strongest elevens of the
East to a score of 14 to 6.
Before that game the only discrepancy in the forecasts was
whether the final score would be
40, or 60, to 0. And yet Hopkins
held Swarthmore to two touchdowns, both made in the first half.
Outweighed, playing against a
frankly superior team, Hopkins
gritted its teeth and fought—and
fought so well that the struggle
became equal.
The team has found itself; the
University is lined up behind it;
all Hopkins is in fighting trim.
Whether we win the championship or lose it, there could have
been no better prelude to the first
real struggle for its possession
than last Saturday's defeat.
An Inadvisable Change.

Since its first publication, the
Hullabaloo has been the book of
one class. In it each successive
group of graduates has found its
expression; consciously or unconsciously, it has depicted the Hopkins senior. For that reason, the
book has meant something—has

been more than a mere publication. It has belonged to the
seniors; they have felt that it has
belonged to them, and they have
made it worthy.
Yet, although the Hullabaloos
of the past have been pre-eminently class books, every under-graduate institution and interest has
had representation in their pages,
every under-graduate class has
had its own separate section—
with the proportion always maintained. A change in Hullabaloo
policy can mean only one thing—
that proportion is to be destroyed; with the exception of the
photographs and write-ups of the
graduates, the Hullabaloo of the
future is not to be a senior book.
Hopkins does not need an under-graduate annal. As a matter
of fact, it does not want an under-graduate annal. The Hullabaloo should be supported by
every under-classman, but it
should be supported because it is
a Hopkins institution, not because
that under-classman happens to
have a photograph displayed on
one of its pages.
In the Hullabaloos of the past,
the seniors have been given that
peculiar sense of individual possession that comes to men when
they feel that a thing has grown
up in their own image. The Hullabaloo, as a class book, has been
a personal bond between those,
who, for four years, have worked
and lived together, a bond that an
under-graduate annal could never
be. The Hullabaloo has belonged
to the seniors—and it has belonged to them of right.
This is not the narrower policy;
it is the broader one. Breadth of
vision does not necessarily go
with mere expanse of canvas.
And, because it has been the book
of one class and one class alone,
the Hullabaloo of the past has reflected its University in the only
way that a University can be reflected in printed pages—in the
tone in which those pages are conceived.
TIIE NEWS-LETTER has the greatest respect for the opinions of the
members of the 1917 Hullabaloo
Board, but if feels constrained to
state that it believes the change
which that board has announced
in the nature of the Hullabaloo
to be an inadvisable one.

The action which created the

The Battalion.

That the inauguration of military training has met with the approval of the Hopkins student
body, and that the battalion itself is in a highly satisfactory
state of development, the drills on
the campus are evidencing without a shadow of doubt. Lieutenant Elliott has shown himself to
be an organizer who knows how to
combine the necessary amount of
disciplinary strictness with the
rare capacity of arousing and sustaining undergraduate enthusiasm, and the heartiness of the response with which he has met has
been unmistakable.
There is a peculiarly exhilarating sensation in being in the forerank of a movement, especially
when that movement has already
met with nation-wide approval.
Military training at colleges, it
must be remembered, save in cadet
institutions of long standing, is
scarcely a year old — and last
spring men were drilling in front
of Gilman Hall. We have not, of
course, made as rapid strides in
the movement as have such univerThe "Pep" Committee.

Yet the appeal has gone out for

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 6, 1916.

Herbert Baxter Adams Leader ofAmerican Historical Study
WAS EDITOR OF COLLEGE PAPER

WORK AT HOPKINS POINTED WAY
Organized First Historical Seminary in
America--President Wilson Calls
Him "Captain of Systematic Scholarship."
By PROF. JOHN H. LATANE'

is hard for those of us who
were here in the nineties to realize that to the students now in
residence, and even to some members of the faculty, Herbert B.
Adams is merely a name. To us
he is still a very real personality.
We remember him as the embodiment of energy and initiative, influential in all University affairs
and actively interested in those
matters which touched the life of
the community, for he believed
with Jules Siegfried that the
"education of the people is the
first duty of democracy."
Adams was a native of Massachusetts, and came of old New
England stock. After graduating
from Amherst College and teaching Latin, Greek, mathematics
and classical history at Williston
Seminary for a year, he went to
Germany, and in 1870 received
the degree of doctor of philosophy
at Heidelberg. That very year
the - Johns Hopkins University
opened its doors to students, offering opportunities for investigation and research which had
never before been available in
America. Adams at once applied
for and was awarded a fellowship
and was thus the first appointee
to that honor in'the department
of history. He held in succession
the positions of lecturer, associate, associate professor and professor, and his connection with
the University continued until
shortly before his death in 1901.
Adams' activities at the Johns
Hopkins University were so
varied that it is impossible to
speak of them all in this brief
sketch. He organized the first historical seminary in America, and,
in order to provide for the publication of his own monographs and
those of his students, he started
the studies in historical and political science. During his lifetime
he edited about forty volumes,
and since his death one or more
volumes have been issued each
year. This series revolutionized
the study of history in America.
His students were set to work on
special topics in limited fields of
investigation. His first students
were drawn mainly from New England, and they were put to work
on the local history of the New
England States. Soon, however,
graduate students came to Baltimore from Virginia and the other
Southern States, and they were
set to work on the local and institutional history of the South.
Adams realized that the history
of the United States could not be
It

With this issue, THE NEWS-LETTER begins a series of
articles upon the lives and works of some of the men whose
efforts, more than any other factor, have given the Johns
Hopkins University the reputation which it enjoys today.
Herbert Baxter Adams may truly be called the father of
modern historical study in America. Through the ideals which
he shaped at this University, a new conception of historical research was spread among the intellectual centers of the country. In him was personified the breadth of thought, the
passion for truth, the vision, which have come down to us as
the most cherished traditions of the Hopkins scholar.
Yet, absorbed in his work as he was, Adams always took
a keen interest in undergraduate affairs. The memory of that
interest is perpetuated by the Adams medal, given every year,
through his generosity,to the best public speaker in the second
year, by the Adams prize of books, awarded at the annual
Senior-Junior debate, and by the Adams Literary Society,
named in his honor.
written on a large scale until
local and obscure sources were
made available through monographs in the field of biography
and local history. The monographic method which he employed was soon adopted in other
American universities, and the
Studies in Historical and Political
Science have been widely imitated
until now almost every university
in the land has a series of its own.
Adams was not a profound
scholar, for his interests took too
wide a range. Neither did he
leave behind him any great piece
of historical work, for, with the

exception of his "Life of Jared
Sparks," an excellent biography
in two volumes, his own contributions were chiefly monographic.
But it is as an organizer of historical studies and a promoter of
new methods of historical research that he will be remembered. His enthusiasm was contagious, and this was the secret..
of his great success. He had the
rare faculty of making his students
think that the subject which
claimed his attention for the time
being in his lecture courses was
the most important subject in the

HERBERT BAXTER ADAMS

Historian Ascribed Much of His Later
Interest in Editing to Early Journalistic Training—Sketch
of His Career.

Herbert Baxter Adams was
born at Shutesbury (near Amherst), Mass., on April 16, 1850.
Doctor Adams' early life was
spent amidst the pleasant surroundings of Hampshire County.
His mother and father were both
of hearty New England stock,
• their Puritan ancestors first settling in Massachusetts in 1634.
Adams' education and training
was in large part due to the kindly help and advice of his eldest brother, Charles Dickinson
Adams.
Adams' mother had moved with
her sons, after their father's
death, to Amherst. It was in the
classical environment of this town
that Adams had his first schooling. Later, his eldest brother was
instrumental in having him enter
Phillips Exeter Academy. Here
he graduated at the head of his
class in 1868. The next fall he
entered Amherst College, winning
the Porter prize for the best entrance examinations.
It was while at Amherst that the
first real influences were present
that developed in Doctor Adams
his remarkable abilities as a
teacher and an editor. He did
not decide to make history his
life work until his last year at
college; in fact, he did not specialize in history until he took up
graduate work after leaving Amherst. President Seelye, of Amherst, was the man who decided
Adams on his career. In one of
his philosophy lectures President
Seelye, who had long known and
helped Adams, discussed the philosophy of history. It was this
lecture that turned Adams toward
the study which he made his life
work.
Before that time, Herbert
Adams had looked forward to
journalism as a profession. He
had reported at odd times for
Amherst, New York and Boston
papers, and had spent many hours
of his time in college in writing
for his college paper.
Adams once said of this: "My
editorial connection with The
Amherst Student really gave a
permanent bent- to my life. I
learned more real useful knowledge in that voluntary connection
than in all other college means
of training; in punctuation, composition, and rhetoric. To this
day I can discern more lasting
influences proceeding from that
editorial den of mine at Amherst
than from any other one college
source. I have forgotten my
mathematics, which I always
(Continued on page 9, col. I)

In 1872 Doctor Adams graduated from Amherst at the head of
his class. He then taught for a
year at Williston Seminary, where
he instructed in Latin, Greek, mathematics and classical history.
After teaching for a year at Williston, his elder brother persuaded him to go to Germany and
take up the graduate work in history.
He first went to Lausanne,
Switzerland, where he studied
French. This was followed by a
few months' study in Italy, after
which he came to Paris. Here his
elder brother, on a trip abroad,
met him and persuaded him to go
to Heidelberg immediately. He
studied at this institution for a
year, and the following winter
saw him at the University of Berlin. Becoming disheartened the
next season at the thought of the
elaborate course of study necessary for a doctor's degree.at Berlin, he decided to return to America, and was' only persuaded to
stay in Germany by his brother,
who influenced him through his
letters to return to Heidelberg.
Here, in 1876, he completed a
course in historical and political
science, under the guidance of
Prof. J. C. Bluntschli, who was
largely instrumental in having

Adams appointed the first Fellow
in history at the Johns Hopkins
University, when the University
was opened in 1876. Adams received his doctor's degree at Heidelberg with highest honors.

An Appreciation.

To the Editor of THE News-LEI-ma:
Sir—If Hopkins were the butt
of a few things as "rotten"—that
is what the powers-that-be called
it—as was "A Would-Be Rooter's"
letter, maybe we would find a
place on the sporting page of an
out-of-town daily. Perhaps the
vapors that hang over the stagnate managerial pool are not as
dense as "A Would-Be Rooter"
has pictured them, but at that
there's something rotten in Denmark, and it isn't last week's
bomb. All the folks agreed it
wasn't the letter that packed the
mass-meeting Wednesday! It was
the temperature or the canning
industry in Alaska, perhaps. And
maybe, the Aurora Borealis woke
the juniors up and made them
start something! It wasn't the
letter—oh, no!
The man who wrote that letter
slipped up once or twice — he
didn't quite get all of his arguments across—but he should be
congratulated upon raising a lone,
courageous voice in the hour of
Hopkins' dire need. Let the
various managers and their assistants stop telling us about the
letter and show us something—
something really constructive.
Let's have rallies before the
games, and give the teams sendoffs on the last practices—not a
half-hearted "hullabaloo," but a
parade and demonstration. Let's
have a truly Hopkins team, and
then we will develop a truly Hopkins spirit. Far better a 99-pound
freshman who is out every day for
practice on the line than an indifferent "Med" who has to be
begged to play.
Hats off to the lone voice from
the darkness!
ANOTHER WOULD-BE ROOTER.
November 1, 1916.
Another.

To the Editor of THE NEws-LETTEE:
Sir — Allow me to congratulate, through your columns, the
"Would-Be Rooter" who has so
aptly and fearlessly expressed the
sentiments of many others beside
himself, concerning the football
situation. He has, to my mind,
shown the conditions in their true
light. Our Athletic Association
must discard its antediluvian
ideas and principles, or else we
must discard our antediluvian
Athletic Association and form a
new and up-to-date one in its

place. Year after year, have our
athletics been allowed to drift—
we have not endeavored to keep
pace with the modernized systems
of other universities. Our Athletic Association is not asleep it
is dead. And unless it is resurrected quickly, the last rites must
be administered, and a new. Athletic Association must be formed,
with the energy and ability to
put through its plans.
Can you "resurrect," Athletic
Association?
Prove it!
What are you going to do about
daylight practice?
What are you going to do about
the persuasion of stubborn parents of good football material?
What are you going to do about
a real band?
What are you going to do about
the fellows who won't yell?
How are you going to solve the
X.
football situation?
November 1, 1916.

To the Editor of THE NEws-LtrrEE:
Sir — I wish to express my
hearty approval of the "Would-Be
Rooter's" article which appeared
in last week's issue of THE NEWSLETTER. I Wish to express my approval and to add more concerning things that have come to light
since that article appeared.
First and foremost is the comeback in spirit that Hopkins had
last week and which was manifest
in the splendid fight which the
football team put up against
Swarthmore. If anyone who saw
Hopkins play on Saturday for the
first time had been told that Hopkins' spirit had been admitted by
almost everyone a week before to
be nil, he would have laughed at
the very idea. Whether it was
the 1918 "Pep" Committee or the
"Would-Be Rooter's" letter that
started the awakening, we do not
know. At any rate, the old-time
spirit has returned.
Next comes the proposed Medical School team. Every Hopkins
student appreciates the feeling
that has urged the medical men
to action. But is it fair to the
undergraduates who have played
on the team so far, to the few
medical students who have conscientiously worked for the team
all season and to the other Maryland State teams to put a team
of stars from other colleges on
the field and call them Hopkins'
team? If we are to have a team
of Penfields and Leadbetters, why
does not the Athletic Association
arrange a schedule that includes
teams of the class these men are
accustomed to oppose? In my
opinion, and in the opinion of
many other Hopkins students, it
is far better to have a team on the
field that will fight like our team
did against Swarthmore and lose,
than to accept the charity of
the medical students and win.

November 4, 1916.
Down With College Spirit!

the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Sir—Your columns this year
have been filled with appeals for
"college spirit." May I venture
a lone voice against "college
spirit" and all that comes with it.
The undergraduate department is
at present in a state of transition.
It has two possibilities:
1. To lose its individuality
and become an average, small college, examples of which are dotted
all over the country. Sad to say,
the removal to Homewood, from
which so much was expected, is
facilitating that. •
2. The other possibility is to
return to the place we occupied
ten years ago. To have the undergraduate department be a vital
part of that institution of learning we so proudly call "The Johns
Hopkins University." I therefor
wish to sound a call for "university spirit," a spirit which should
strive for things higher than a
State football championship.
JUNIOR.
October 31, 1916.
To

Re-enter the "Would-Be Rooter."
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LEVER:

Sir—Have we no pride? Have
we no self-respect? Are we totally
void of any self-esteem? Reports
are being circulated that the
Medical School is organizing a
football team of "old-timers," and
lacks but three backfield men.
We are to supply them. Then,
these veterans are to proceed to
win the Maryland (minus Annapolis) State championship. Is
there no one else in this whole
University who will stand up with
me and say: "We don't want
them !" We don't want the State
championship if we must take
second-hand players, who have left
their college spirit with their respective colleges, and are at Hopkins to study medicine! We don't
want the State championship
anyway, because it has no meaning!
Wake up Does no one realize
that this is no way to carry on
our athletics? I reiterate that
we must stop the Athletic Association from pursuing its
policy: "Give us enough ready developed men and we will turn out
a successful team." Examine the
list of men on this Medical School
team, as given by The Sun. Few
are Hopkins men who have spent
their under-graduate days playing for us. Two are Princeton

men, one having been a varsity
player in 1912. Three have already been captains at their respective colleges. Do you get my
point? Why should we be thrilled
by the performance of such men?
We should be ashamed to appear
at all within Homewood field, to
acknowledge that such is the
team we adnlit to be our representative.
Suppose these old-timers, in
spite of their radiantly glorious
reputation, proceed to lose the
Western Maryland game. What
then? Will an all-providing Athletic Association proceed to call
a special session and agree to
spend a few extra dollars and
have the "band" on the field Monday afternoon at the beginning of
practice? Will the four undergraduate classes appear in a mass
and march around the field and
cheer themselves hoarse to show
the team (the old-timers) that in
spite of the fact that they have
lost the State championship
there is still the St. John's game?
That is virtually what occurred at
the University of Pennsylvania
after they lost their first game.
But, will we do it? Why should
we do it? It certainly won't make
the old-timers play better!
But, suppose they win—what a
glorious victory it will be! How
proud we shall be of our University! The first real game for the
State championship will have been
won—through charity. Or, do
you frankly believe that these oldtimers are to play spontaneously,
because of their love for Johns
Hopkins University?
The prime object of a team is
not merely to win games (for if it
were we could hire professionals) ;
its object is to represent its college
upon the athletic field. To accept
such a team as we are about to
place in the field is to admit that
the undergraduate department is
a nonentity. Why should we
come week after week to see a
team consisting of men whom we
hardly know to speak to, except
perhaps through our fraternal
affiliation? If, however, we are to
accept this Medical School team,
I respectfully suggest to the Athletic Association that it organize
four class teams and conduct a
series of interclass games. Personally, I would rather root for
my class team than for a team of
men whom I don't know to speak
to, even though the latter be playing for the "State" championship.

The stands fairly went wild
with excitement, for at last it
looked like a sure touchdown for
Hopkins. Captain Brooks was

in the same position as before.
With but one down left in which
to carry the ball over, Gatchell
was sent in with instructions
which resulted in an off-tackle
play for a touchdown. Martin,
quarterback, faked a pass to
Brooks, who paved the way for
Byrd Hopkins to take the ball
across. Branham failed at goal.
The resulting touchdown was a
virtual victory for the Black and
Blue. When the half ended a
few minutes later 'the Hopkins
student body rushed out on the
field to congratulate the members
of its team. An impromptu snake
dance was given, and after a
large "H" had been formed in the
center of the field, the students
retired to outside the locker
room, where Coach Brennick, Assistant Coach Wilkinson and
every member of the Black and
Blue team was given a hearty and
well-rounded cheer. The scene in
many ways resembled the winning
of an important State game and
emphasized the added interest
taken in the team during the past
week.
Swarthmore scored her two
touchdowns during the first part
of the first quarter. When the Quakers got the ball in the opening period they were unable to
advance the pigskin by straight
line plays and so were compelled
to rely on the aerial route. The
ball was gradually worked up
through Hopkins' territory on a
series of beautiful forward passes.
Finally, the visitors were within
striking distance of goal and
again failing to gain through the
line, attempted a pass, which this
time failed of completion. The ball
went over the goal line and was
given to Hopkins. Gorman punted and the Quakers, having the
ball once more, settled down for
a touchdown. Additional forward
passes by Swarthmore, and the
ball was on Hopkins' 10-yard line.
Hopkins' line braced, but was unable to hold the Quakers, and the
pigskin was taken over for the
first touchdown of the game by
Cornog, fullback for Swarthmore.
Michael kicked goal.
Hopkins kept the ball in
Swarthmore territory during almost the entire second half, but
was never able to get within striking distance of goal until the last
few minutes of play.
A feature of the third quarter
was an end run by Branham.
Jack tore around right end for a
40-yard run that looked good for
a touchdown until he was upset
just 12 yards from the goal line.
